<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">

<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>What is the goal of Life? To accumulate the most money.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That’s what I learned from reading the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/20/business/reuben-klamer-dead.html?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">obituary</a> of Reuben Klamer, the creator of the board game, The Game of Life, who died this week at 99.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When The Game of Life was introduced, in 1960, the purpose was to earn the most wealth. The way you got there was simple enough—by going to college, getting a job, buying insurance, saving for retirement. That was “indicative of what sold in that era,” a former Hasbro VP told the NYT.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Over time, designers realized that the game didn’t reflect consumers’ changing views of #lifegoals. So they gave it a big update in 2007, allowing players to score points for virtuous deeds like saving an endangered species, opening a health-food chain, and recycling. And instead of starting the game at point A and finishing at point Z, there is no fixed path: You decide how you want to spend your time.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One question that popped up for me: If the popular view of what matters in life changed so much in less than 50 years, who’s to say it won’t shift again in the next 50? How will you win Life in 2057?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>

</tr>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers with...Gritty
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/25/icebreakers-with-gritty?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Gritty in front of Philadelphia skyline" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/ecc20f96adcea42e1a4814d3e960547380638f90-2573x1716.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em><em>Philadelphia Flyers</em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When it comes to Gritty, the quintessential mascot (of the NHL’s Philadelphia Flyers), you’re either scared of what he’s capable of or scared of how much you love him. Sometimes it’s both. However you feel about this giant orange chaos monster, you can’t deny that he’s a marketing masterpiece; a living, breathing meme; and that he is now three years old after <a href="https://twitter.com/GrittyNHL/status/1441371046876168192?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">celebrating</a> his birthday on Friday (but rumor has it that he has been around for <a href="https://www.nhl.com/flyers/fans/gritty?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>much</em></a> longer).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Morning Brew caught up with Gritty to discuss the big three: social media, sports, and Philly cheesesteaks.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If Gritty went public as a company, what would your trading ticker be?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">GRITTY. I’m already public. I may root for the Flyers but I belong to the people.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>On balance, do you think social media is good or bad for society?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yes, I do. There’s a lot of negativity on the internet and oftentimes it finds those who go looking for it. I like to keep my ish positive and entertaining for my Gritizens.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What do you see as the main purpose of a sports mascot?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I guess your typical sports mascot exists to take photos with fans, start a few crowd chants, and support the local community. I do that stuff, too, though I wouldn’t describe myself as typical. To quote my second favorite playwright: “I am not what I am.”—Willy Shakespeare</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I think what Mr. Shakespeare was trying to say was that although I am a sports mascot, I don’t allow the construct of sports mascottery to define who I am or what I do. I have so much more to give.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Pat’s or Geno’s?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Any true Philadelphian knows that you can’t provide a correct answer to a wrong question.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Would you ever go solo?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Never.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Which social platform is best for engagement with fans?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">They all have their perks I guess. I like to engage with my Gritizens the old-fashioned way: face to fur.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What’s the best hockey movie?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There are the obvious picks...<em>Miracle</em>, <em>Mighty Ducks</em>, <em>The Tooth Fairy</em> starring Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson (ppl don’t talk about it but this movie put DJ on the map...there is no <em>Jungle Cruise</em> without <em>The Tooth Fairy</em>), but the best hockey movie is easily <em>MVP: Most Valuable Primate</em>. Sometimes I just kick my feet up at lunch and throw it in my Blu-ray player. That whole <em>MVP</em> trilogy will go down as one of the best in modern cinema. How they ever found a chimpanzee that was good at hockey, skateboarding, and snowboarding is beyond me. But that’s Hollywood.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you find yourself wanting more Gritty (and who doesn’t?), you can read our full interview <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/25/icebreakers-with-gritty?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited, condensed, and translated from Gritty’s native tongue for clarity.</em></p>
</div>


</div>
</td>
</tr>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Is My Boss Clueless or a Simply a Jerk?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/24/make-it-work-is-my-boss-clueless-or-just-a-jerk?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Boss from Office Space " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Giphy </em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I am a senior-level manager at a company of about 125 people. Recently, my organization held its first big summer outing in two years—and my first, since I had only been with the company for 12 months. It was a sunset tour around the bay, drink tickets included. I had to skip the event to meet a compressed deadline. I was the only one in my relatively small department who could not go. My boss never inquired ahead of time nor said anything afterward about my not being able to attend. Is he a clueless jerk for this, or thems just the breaks?—Maureen</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I’ll start by making the case for your boss: Some people value and practice discretion differently than others—if your boss is still getting to know you, there’s a decent chance that his not inquiring about your RSVP was out of respect for your privacy (as opposed to being too busy divvying up your allotted drink tickets). Incidentally, consider that he may not realize that the reason you had to pass was in fact work-related.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Even as we extend some benefit of the doubt, it’s hard to justify the fact that he hasn’t checked in afterward with something as simple as, “We missed you at the summer outing!” I suppose there are further limbs we could climb out on—him not wanting to make you feel bad about having missed out, or perhaps you’ve been appointed as the <em>Designated Survivor</em> of the organization and they’ve simply neglected to tell you. However you slice it, though, it’s just not a great look.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Having established that I’m “Team Maureen,” where do we go from here? Before pressing George Costanza’s <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bU2cLeWBH7U" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jerk store line</a> into action, it’s worth considering how your first 12 months have gone otherwise. Was this omission part of a broader pattern of behavior from your boss, or an isolated act of thoughtlessness? If the former, I think you owe it to yourself to have a conversation with him about the impact these actions are having on your overall job satisfaction.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If the incident feels more singular, I might leave it alone at this point (although if you wanted to address it, I wouldn’t blame you). When the next company outing rolls around, initiate a chat with your boss about any conflicting work on your team’s plate. If there’s no realistic solution where everyone can attend without jeopardizing a key deadline, then perhaps it’s someone else’s turn to sit a good time out. Your department may be small, but there’s no reason ’dem breaks (and ’dem drink tickets) can’t be distributed equitably.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Write in here</a>. And coming soon...HR Brew. Be one of the <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first subscribers</a> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>
</div>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
The Legend of the $1 Trillion Platinum Coin<br>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/24/the-legend-of-the-usd1-trillion-platinum-coin?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Coin spinning" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/14cb7e0ab683e523ada0cd71fcb414cb308606c6-480x328.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Giphy</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You may have heard that a deadline to suspend the debt ceiling is rapidly approaching, and if lawmakers don’t do anything it could lead to “<a href="https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/yellen-debt-ceiling-economic-catastrophe?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">economic catastrophe</a>,” in the words of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But what if we told you there was a solution to the debt ceiling fiasco <em>so</em> crazy...it just might work?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The solution:</strong> Yellen could have the Treasury mint a $1 trillion platinum coin, deposit it at the Fed to “retire” loads of US federal debt, and then enable the government to carry on with business as usual without having to worry about defaulting on its existing debt.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>But can the Treasury really do that? </strong>Yes. According to <a href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5112?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Section 31 US Code § 5112</a>...</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px"><li><span>“The Secretary may mint and issue platinum bullion coins and proof platinum coins in accordance with such specifications, designs, varieties, quantities, denominations, and inscriptions as the Secretary, in the Secretary’s discretion, may prescribe from time to time.”</span></li></ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The law is crystal clear, and has been <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/legendary-harvard-law-professor-gives-the-ultimate-verdict-on-whether-the-trillion-dollar-platinum-coin-is-legal-2013-1?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deemed kosher</a> by numerous academics. “The statute clearly does authorize the issuance of trillion-dollar coins,” Laurence Tribe, a Harvard Law professor, told Washington Monthly back in 2013.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In fact, nothing says we have to stop at $1 trillion. Yellen could go big with a $10 trillion coin, hypothetically. As Bloomberg’s Joe Weisenthal explains, none of this would lead to inflation because it’s merely an “<a href="https://twitter.com/TheStalwart/status/1441005132641095680?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">accounting trick</a>”—not an influx of money into the economy.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Have we tried this before?</strong> The $1 trillion platinum coin idea seems to pop up every time the US faces a debt ceiling crunch. It was first <a href="https://www.wired.com/2013/01/trillion-dollar-coin-inventor/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">introduced</a> by a Georgia lawyer in 2010 and gained traction during the debt-ceiling crisis of 2011.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Things really turned up in 2013, when the government was...you guessed it, facing another debt ceiling deadline. The hashtag #MintTheCoin became popular on Twitter, and economists like Paul Krugman advocated for unleashing the coin. “If we have a crisis over the debt ceiling, it will be only because the Treasury Department would rather see economic devastation than look silly for a couple of minutes,” he <a href="https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/09/barbarous-relics/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But each time the $1 trillion coin is mentioned as a way of resolving debt ceiling problems, the people in charge dismiss it as a <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/trillion-dollar-coin-on-debt-ceiling-treasury-2015-10?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">distraction</a> from Congress doing its job. “Neither the Treasury nor the Federal Reserve believes that the law can or should be used to produce platinum coins for the purpose of avoiding an increase in the debt limit,” The Treasury wrote during...well, yes, another debt ceiling emergency in 2015.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As for our current predicament, the Biden administration <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/mint-1-trillion-platinum-coin-debt-ceiling-2021-9?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rejected</a> the minting of the $1 trillion coin yet again last week.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>Perhaps some enterprising future Treasury Secretary will manifest the platinum coin into existence, but for now it remains as mythical as Camelot.</p>
</div>

Open House
</h1>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that is so fall-themed right now it HURTS. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess how much it costs.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c12ed1d44e738f01e9366a28972d2f6f5dc3bb2a-1200x675.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format" alt="Yellow Vintage Colonial home in Maine with bonus log cabin and red barn." style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important"><p><em>CIRCA</em></p><p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Today’s <a href="https://circaoldhouses.com/property/vintage-colonial-with-post-and-beam-barn-and-log-cabin-on-27-acres/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">listing</a> is located in Woolwich, Maine, about a 40-minute drive south of the capital, Augusta. Woolwich is surrounded by three different rivers and Merrymeeting Bay, so this home is technically on a peninsula (go geography!). This 8,000-square-foot Vintage Colonial was built in 1780 and is what true autumn dreams are made of. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>5 beds, 5 baths</span></li>
<li><span>Bonus log cabin AND barn</span></li>
<li><span>HUGE porch you could get lost in</span></li>
<li><span>At least 20 Revolutionary War ghosts</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to curl up by one of the many fireplaces and sip hot cider in the Maine countryside?</p>

style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eWhat is the goal of Life? To accumulate the most money.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThat’s what I learned from reading the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/20/business/reuben-klamer-dead.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eobituary\u003c/a\u003e of Reuben Klamer, the creator of the board game, The Game of Life, who died this week at 99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen The Game of Life was introduced, in 1960, the purpose was to earn the most wealth. The way you got there was simple enough—by going to college, getting a job, buying insurance, saving for retirement. That was “indicative of what sold in that era,” a former Hasbro VP told the NYT.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOver time, designers realized that the game didn’t reflect consumers’ changing views of #lifegoals. So they gave it a big update in 2007, allowing players to score points for virtuous deeds like saving an endangered species, opening a health-food chain, and recycling. And instead of starting the game at point A and finishing at point Z, there is no fixed path: You decide how you want to spend your time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne question that popped up for me: If the popular view of what matters in life changed so much in less than 50 years, who’s to say it won’t shift again in the next 50? How will you win Life in 2057?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Gritty in front of Philadelphia skyline\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/ecc20f96adcea42e1a4814d3e960547380638f90-2573x1716.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003ePhiladelphia Flyers\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen it comes to Gritty, the quintessential mascot (of the NHL’s Philadelphia Flyers), you’re either scared of what he’s capable of or scared of how much you love him. Sometimes it’s both. However you feel about this giant orange chaos monster, you can’t deny that he’s a marketing masterpiece; a living, breathing meme; and that he is now three years old after \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/GrittyNHL/status/1441371046876168192?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecelebrating\u003c/a\u003e his birthday on Friday (but rumor has it that he has been around for \u003ca href=\"https://www.nhl.com/flyers/fans/gritty?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003emuch\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e longer).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMorning Brew caught up with Gritty to discuss the big three: social media, sports, and Philly cheesesteaks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf Gritty went public as a company, what would your trading ticker be?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eGRITTY. I’m already public. I may root for the Flyers but I belong to the people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOn balance, do you think social media is good or bad for society?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYes, I do. There’s a lot of negativity on the internet and oftentimes it finds those who go looking for it. I like to keep my ish positive and entertaining for my Gritizens.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat do you see as the main purpose of a sports mascot?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI guess your typical sports mascot exists to take photos with fans, start a few crowd chants, and support the local community. I do that stuff, too, though I wouldn’t describe myself as typical. To quote my second favorite playwright: “I am not what I am.”—Willy Shakespeare\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI think what Mr. Shakespeare was trying to say was that although I am a sports mascot, I don’t allow the construct of sports mascottery to define who I am or what I do. I have so much more to give.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePat’s or Geno’s?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAny true Philadelphian knows that you can’t provide a correct answer to a wrong question.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWould you ever go solo?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNever.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhich social platform is best for engagement with fans?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThey all have their perks I guess. I like to engage with my Gritizens the old-fashioned way: face to fur.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat’s the best hockey movie?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere are the obvious picks...\u003cem\u003eMiracle\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eMighty Ducks\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eThe Tooth Fairy\u003c/em\u003e starring Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson (ppl don’t talk about it but this movie put DJ on the map...there is no \u003cem\u003eJungle Cruise\u003c/em\u003e without \u003cem\u003eThe Tooth Fairy\u003c/em\u003e), but the best hockey movie is easily \u003cem\u003eMVP: Most Valuable Primate\u003c/em\u003e. Sometimes I just kick my feet up at lunch and throw it in my Blu-ray player. That whole \u003cem\u003eMVP\u003c/em\u003e trilogy will go down as one of the best in modern cinema. How they ever found a chimpanzee that was good at hockey, skateboarding, and snowboarding is beyond me. But that’s Hollywood.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you find yourself wanting more Gritty (and who doesn’t?), you can read our full interview \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/25/icebreakers-with-gritty?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited, condensed, and translated from Gritty’s native tongue for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- END SOCIAL LINKS - --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- END ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003c!-- SPONSORED SECTION --\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Boss from Office Space \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGiphy \u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI am a senior-level manager at a company of about 125 people. Recently, my organization held its first big summer outing in two years—and my first, since I had only been with the company for 12 months. It was a sunset tour around the bay, drink tickets included. I had to skip the event to meet a compressed deadline. I was the only one in my relatively small department who could not go. My boss never inquired ahead of time nor said anything afterward about my not being able to attend. Is he a clueless jerk for this, or thems just the breaks?—Maureen\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI’ll start by making the case for your boss: Some people value and practice discretion differently than others—if your boss is still getting to know you, there’s a decent chance that his not inquiring about your RSVP was out of respect for your privacy (as opposed to being too busy divvying up your allotted drink tickets). Incidentally, consider that he may not realize that the reason you had to pass was in fact work-related.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEven as we extend some benefit of the doubt, it’s hard to justify the fact that he hasn’t checked in afterward with something as simple as, “We missed you at the summer outing!” I suppose there are further limbs we could climb out on—him not wanting to make you feel bad about having missed out, or perhaps you’ve been appointed as the \u003cem\u003eDesignated Survivor\u003c/em\u003e of the organization and they’ve simply neglected to tell you. However you slice it, though, it’s just not a great look.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHaving established that I’m “Team Maureen,” where do we go from here? Before pressing George Costanza’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bU2cLeWBH7U\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejerk store line\u003c/a\u003e into action, it’s worth considering how your first 12 months have gone otherwise. Was this omission part of a broader pattern of behavior from your boss, or an isolated act of thoughtlessness? If the former, I think you owe it to yourself to have a conversation with him about the impact these actions are having on your overall job satisfaction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf the incident feels more singular, I might leave it alone at this point (although if you wanted to address it, I wouldn’t blame you). When the next company outing rolls around, initiate a chat with your boss about any conflicting work on your team’s plate. If there’s no realistic solution where everyone can attend without jeopardizing a key deadline, then perhaps it’s someone else’s turn to sit a good time out. Your department may be small, but there’s no reason ’dem breaks (and ’dem drink tickets) can’t be distributed equitably.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWrite in here\u003c/a\u003e. background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nThe Legend of the $1 Trillion Platinum Coin\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/24/the-legend-of-the-usd1-trillion-platinum-coin?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Coin spinning\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/14cb7e0ab683e523ada0cd71fcb414cb308606c6-480x328.gif?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou may have heard that a deadline to suspend the debt ceiling is rapidly approaching, and if lawmakers don’t do anything it could lead to “\u003ca href=\"https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/yellen-debt-ceiling-economic-catastrophe?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeconomic catastrophe\u003c/a\u003e,” in the words of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut what if we told you there was a solution to the debt ceiling fiasco \u003cem\u003eso\u003c/em\u003e crazy...it just might work?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe solution:\u003c/strong\u003e Yellen could have the Treasury mint a $1 trillion platinum coin, deposit it at the Fed to “retire” loads of US federal debt, and then enable the government to carry on with business as usual without having to worry about defaulting on its existing debt.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBut can the Treasury really do that? \u003c/strong\u003eYes. According to \u003ca href=\"https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5112?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSection 31 US Code § 5112\u003c/a\u003e...\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The Secretary may mint and issue platinum bullion coins and proof platinum coins in accordance with such specifications, designs, varieties, quantities, denominations, and inscriptions as the Secretary, in the Secretary’s discretion, may prescribe from time to time.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe law is crystal clear, and has been \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/legendary-harvard-law-professor-gives-the-ultimate-verdict-on-whether-the-trillion-dollar-platinum-coin-is-legal-2013-1?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeemed kosher\u003c/a\u003e by numerous academics. “The statute clearly does authorize the issuance of trillion-dollar coins,” Laurence Tribe, a Harvard Law professor, told Washington Monthly back in 2013.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn fact, nothing says we have to stop at $1 trillion. Yellen could go big with a $10 trillion coin, hypothetically. As Bloomberg’s Joe Weisenthal explains, none of this would lead to inflation because it’s merely an “\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TheStalwart/status/1441005132641095680?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccounting trick\u003c/a\u003e”—not an influx of money into the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHave we tried this before?\u003c/strong\u003e The $1 trillion platinum coin idea seems to pop up every time the US faces a debt ceiling crunch. It was first \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/2013/01/trillion-dollar-coin-inventor/?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eintroduced\u003c/a\u003e by a Georgia lawyer in 2010 and gained traction during the debt-ceiling crisis of 2011.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThings really turned up in 2013, when the government was...you guessed it, facing another debt ceiling deadline. The hashtag #MintTheCoin became popular on Twitter, and economists like Paul Krugman advocated for unleashing the coin. “If we have a crisis over the debt ceiling, it will be only because the Treasury Department would rather see economic devastation than look silly for a couple of minutes,” he \u003ca href=\"https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/09/barbarous-relics/?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px
